text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IRM 25.5.8.1 added to include Internal Controls as required by IRM 1.11.2, Internal Management Document System, Internal Revenue Manuel (IRM) Process.
IRM 25.5.8.2.2(3) clariﬁed procedures for the TEGE Area Manager to verbally approve summonses to a political organization in situations requiring expeditious handling.

25.5.8.3.1.1 added a Note to explain that requests for information regarding the ﬁling or failure to ﬁle a tax or information return by the church is considered a routine request and a Note was added advising that churches are not required to ﬁle annual information returns (Form 990).
IRM 25.5.8.3.2(3) added procedures for follow up of the church tax inquiry before referencing the church tax examination procedures. Also added references to IRM 4.75.39.7.7 and IRM 25.5.8.3.3.
25.5.8.3.3 changed to conform to the procedures reﬂected in IRM 4.75.39.

IRM 25.5.8.3.3(4) reference to Area Counsel updated to TEGEDC Area Counsel and Note changed to reﬂect that the designated official under IRC 7611(b) is the Commissioner TEGE and that approval under IRC 7611(f) is to be made by the Deputy Commissioner for Services and Enforcement. A reference to Delegation Order 7-3 (Rev. 2) in IRM 1.2.2 was added.
25.5.8.3.4 highlighting emphasis added to improve clarity.
25.5.8.3.5(4) references to Area Counsel updated to TEGEDC Area Counsel.
IRM 25.5.8.4(2) updated to reﬂect IRM language speciﬁc to the EOI Program, removed references Tax Attachés and Revenue Service Representatives and added a reference to IRM 4.60.1.2.2.
IRM 25.5.8.4(2) Note updated to reﬂect that no contact should be made with foreign tax without going through the US Competent Authority.
Throughout this IRM, replaced “examiner” with “IRS employee” since this IRM is used by all IRS employees authorized to issue a summons. Also, replaced “the Service” with “the IRS”.
The revision to this IRM section includes editorial changes, formatting, and IRM reference corrections throughout.
The revision to this IRM section includes editorial changes, formatting, and IRM reference corrections
AUDIENCE
Table of Contents
Special Applications
) The Summons Handbook provides guidelines for all IRS functions in one functional handbook. (

) Purpose: This IRM provides instructional procedures for the use of regarding: • The Finances of a Political Organization • Church Tax Inquiries and Examinations • Tax Treaties • Records Located Outside the United States (
) Audience: All employees conducting such investigations. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy, SBSE. (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy, SBSE, Enforcement. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders include Counsel, Examination and Criminal Investigation, (CI). (

) Program Goals: There are occasions when summonses are required regarding the ﬁnances of a political organization, a church, or involving tax treaties or records located outside the United States. By following this IRM, employees will understand the appropriate use of summonses in these tions. (
) This IRM contains guidance on the restrictions associated with an of political organization ﬁnances and provides instructions for the use of summons authority to facilitate such investigations. (

) This IRM also contains information regarding the restrictions on church tax inquiries, church tax examinations and guidance on issuing church as follows: • Restrictions on church tax inquiries and examinations • Situations when IRC
procedures are not applicable • Collection and TEGE requirements before serving a church • Church tax inquiries • Church tax examinations • IRC
deﬁnitions • Issuing church summonses, and • Guidance for criminal investigation (

) Foreign countries with tax treaties or Tax Information Exchange Agreements (TIEAs) with the United States may request information located within the United States in furtherance of a foreign tax investigation or procedure. such information may be obtainable through a summons issued by the IRS. The IRS is tasked with this activity as is discussed in IRM

, for Information Pursuant to Tax Treaties. Similarly, the IRS may request mation located outside the United States in furtherance of an IRS tax investigation or procedure, where the relevant foreign country has a tax or TIEA with the United States. See IRM
, Records Outside the States.
• IRC

deﬁnitions • Issuing church summonses, and • Guidance for criminal investigation Foreign countries with tax treaties or Tax Information Exchange Agreements (TIEAs) with the United States may request information located within the United States in furtherance of a foreign tax investigation or procedure. Some such information may be obtainable through a summons issued by the IRS. The IRS is tasked with this activity as is discussed in IRM

, Summons for Information Pursuant to Tax Treaties. Similarly, the IRS may request infor- mation located outside the United States in furtherance of an IRS tax investigation or procedure, where the relevant foreign country has a tax treaty or TIEA with the United States. See IRM
, Records Outside the

in IRM

, Servicewide tions of Authority. This approval is evidenced by the signature of the authorizing official on the summons, or by a statement on the summons, signed by the issuing officer, that prior authorization to issue the summons been obtained and stating the name and title of the authorizing official and date of authorization. (

) Additional procedures for the approval and issuance of summonses churches or the ﬁnances of political organizations, summonses for records located outside the United States, and summonses pursuant to tax treaties provided throughout this section. (
) Delegation Order
(Rev
) delegates the authority to begin a church tax inquiry under the requirements of IRC
(a) and to begin a church tax ex- amination under IRC
(b) to the Commissioner, Tax Exempt and Government Entities (TEGE). In situations where a church tax inquiry or ex- amination will begin within the applicable
year period described in IRC
(f) and approval is required under that subsection, the Deputy Commis- sioner for Services and Enforcement is the designated official with approval authority. See IRM
, Servicewide Delegations of Authority. (

) In general, the IRS should issue summonses only when the information is already in the IRS’s possession and the taxpayer (or other witness) will not produce the desired records or other information voluntarily. A summons is speciﬁc to each case. There are no program reports that track summonses third-party witnesses. (
) All IRS employees may use Form
, Summons. When circumstances dictate, Collection employees use Form
, Summons Collection Statement, Form
, Summons Income Tax Return and Form
, Financial Records Summons. See IRM
, Description of Summons, for additional information about summons forms.

) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already exist in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
broad egories. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accordance with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties Accord with Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR, https://www.irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights and Policy Statement
in
, Servicewide Policy Statements. (

) The term political organization includes: • A political party to • A national, state, or local committee of a political party • Campaign committees or other organizations that accept the or make expenditures for inﬂuencing the selection, nomination, or a Political election of any individual for elective public office. The term political organization does not include an organization to which taxpayer is the only contributor. For more information, see IRM
, Political Organization Returns (Form
POL), and IRM
Political Organizations. (
) Political organization ﬁnancial information includes testimony or documents disclose the identity of contributors or recipients of expenditures. (

) A summons may be used to obtain testimony or documents concerning the ﬁnances of a political organization if compliance with the summons would require a general disclosure of the ﬁnances. Such a summons will be to information relating to the tax liability of named taxpayers under or investigation. The summons must speciﬁcally identify the taxpayer’s tions with the political organization and be limited to require only testimony documents relating to those transactions or to other similar transactions. If taxpayer’s transactions with the political organization are known to have occurred through the use of an intermediary person or organization, the summons may require testimony or documents relating to speciﬁcally transactions of the intermediary with the political organization. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
C

A national, state, or local committee of a political party Campaign committees or other organizations that accept contributions or make expenditures for inﬂuencing the selection, nomination, or election of any individual for elective public office.
taxpayer is the only contributor. For more information, see IRM
, Political Organization Returns (Form
POL), and IRM
, Section
Political Organizations. (
) Political organization ﬁnancial information includes testimony or documents that disclose the identity of contributors or recipients of expenditures. (

) A summons may be used to obtain testimony or documents concerning the ﬁnances of a political organization if compliance with the summons would not require a general disclosure of the ﬁnances. Such a summons will be restricted to information relating to the tax liability of named taxpayers under examination or investigation. The summons must speciﬁcally identify the taxpayer’s transac- tions with the political organization and be limited to require only testimony or documents relating to those transactions or to other similar transactions. If the taxpayer’s transactions with the political organization are known to have occurred through the use of an intermediary person or organization, the summons may require testimony or documents relating to speciﬁcally identiﬁed transactions of the intermediary with the political organization.
Political organization ﬁnancial information includes testimony or documents that disclose the identity of contributors or recipients of expenditures.
Special Applications
) Do not use a summons to obtain testimony or documents requiring a disclosure of the ﬁnances of a political organization, except as provided in

, Criminal Investigation and Summons Concerning Finances of a Organization. This restriction applies if the information sought by a would generally disclose the ﬁnances of a political organization even though the testimony is to be obtained from, or the documents are owned or possessed by, a source that is not a political organization. (
) Before issuing a summons, an attempt should be made to obtain the tion without a summons. Refer to IRM
, Requesting Information: Overview; IRM
, Information Reporting and Record Keeping; CCDM
, Formal Document Requests; and IRM
, Interviews: ity and Purpose. (
) If conformity with IRM
or an exception to the provisions of IRM

desired, a memorandum request with a copy of the proposed summons will submitted by the Special Agent in Charge, Criminal Investigation (CI), to the Director, Field Operations, CI, for prior written approval. If time is of the of essence, a telephonic request can be made to the Director, Field CI, followed immediately by a memorandum. (

) If there is a question as to the legal sufficiency of the proposed summons time permits, refer the summons to the appropriate Area Counsel office for a preliminary legal review prior to referral of the request to Headquarters for approval. (

) A summons may be issued to obtain testimony or documents concerning a political organization (whether from the organization itself or from a record- keeper, such as a bank), if needed, to determine the exempt status or tax liability of an organization under examination. Refer to IRM
, Exhibit
, for summons preparation. (

) The TEGE Area Manager must authorize the summons before it is issued. signature must be on the original and all copies of the summons. Official tronic signatures are acceptable. The IRS employee should: a. Prepare a detailed memo to the Area Manager, explaining the need for the summons. b. Retain a copy of such memo in the examination administrative ﬁle. c. Refer any questions about the legal sufficiency of the proposed to TEGEDC Area Counsel for a preliminary legal review before ing it to the Area Manager, for approval. (

) In situations requiring expeditious handling, the Area Manager may give oral authorization to issue a summons to a political organization. A statement signed by the issuing IRS employee, on the original and all copies of the summons, must specify that the IRS employee had prior authorization by Area Manager, and include the date authorized. This statement may be manually or electronically in the “Signature of Approving Officer” blank space on the summons. Such authorization should be conﬁrmed by the Area Manager in writing as soon as possible after the summons is issued.

This statement may be written manually or electronically in the “Signature of Approving Officer” blank space on the summons. Such authorization should be conﬁrmed by the Area
) IRC

imposes restrictions on inquiries or examinations concerning a church. Before the IRS can civilly use any information for an adverse action on Church against a church (e.g., ﬁnal notice of revocation or denial of exempt status, Inquiries and issuance of a notice of deﬁciency, or the assessment of any underpayment of tax), the restrictions of IRC
must ﬁrst be met. Refer to IRM
, Church Tax Inquiries and Examinations Under IRC
, for procedures. (
) IRC
speciﬁcally excludes certain IRS inquiries to churches from the re- strictions it imposes. See IRM
, Situations in Which IRC
in which IRC Procedures Do Not Apply, for a description of these exclusions. Procedures Do Not (
) The restrictions of IRC

do not apply to routine requests. Routine requests are requests for information the IRS needs to administer the Internal Revenue Code apart from requests for information needed to determine an organiza- tion’s exempt status or to assess tax. Routine requests include (but are not limited to) questions regarding:
) IRC

imposes restrictions on inquiries or examinations concerning a church. Before the IRS can civilly use any information for an adverse action on Church against a church (e.g., ﬁnal notice of revocation or denial of exempt status, and issuance of a notice of deﬁciency, or the assessment of any underpayment of tax), the restrictions of IRC
must ﬁrst be met. Refer to IRM
, Church Tax Inquiries and Examinations Under IRC
, for procedures. (
) IRC
speciﬁcally excludes certain IRS inquiries to churches from the re- strictions it imposes. See IRM
, Situations in Which IRC
in which IRC Procedures Do Not Apply, for a description of these exclusions. Do Not (
) The restrictions of IRC

do not apply to routine requests. Routine are requests for information the IRS needs to administer the Internal Revenue Code apart from requests for information needed to determine an organiza- tion’s exempt status or to assess tax. Routine requests include (but are not limited to) questions regarding: a. The ﬁling or failure to ﬁle any tax or information return by the church. b. Compliance with income tax or FICA withholding responsibilities. c. Supplemental information needed to complete the mechanical of any incomplete or incorrect return ﬁled by a church. d. Information needed to process letter ruling requests or applications for exemption. e. Information necessary to process and periodically update registrations tax-free transactions (excise tax), elections for exemptions from windfall proﬁts tax, or employment tax exemption requests by a church. f. Information identifying a church that will be used by the IRS to update its Exempt Organizations Select Check, an on-line search tool that allows users to check certain information about the federal tax statuses and ﬁlings of tax-exempt organizations, and other computer ﬁles, and g. Conﬁrmation that a speciﬁc business is or is not owned or operated by church. Note: Repeated (two or more) failures by the church to respond to routine may support the commencement of a church tax inquiry. Observe the provi- sions of IRC
if a summons is required to secure the information after the failure of the church to respond. (
) The restrictions of IRC

must be observed if an organization claims to be a church. When there is reason to believe an organization’s claim to be a church is frivolous, TEGEDC Area Counsel’s opinion must be secured before determination is made that IRC
is not applicable. (
) IRC
applies to schools operated as part of a church or convention or as- sociation of churches. However, IRC
does not apply to a separately organized or incorporated church-supported school, or other organization porated separately from the church. (
) The provisions of IRC
are not applicable to summonses issued to aid in the collection of liabilities already assessed.

The scope of a church tax examination is limited to determine:
a. The initial or continuing qualiﬁcation of the organization under IRC
), including classiﬁcation as a church under IRC

) A church tax examination can only begin if certain notice of examination and opportunity for conference requirements, set forth in IRC
, are ﬁrst satisﬁed. Refer to IRM
, Church Tax Examination, for church tax ex- amination procedures. (
) To initiate a Notice of Examination, the IRS employee will prepare a draft notice of examination for the signature of the designated official. See IRM

, Preparing the Notice of Examination. Before sending the Notice Examination to the designated official for approval, the IRS employee must forward the entire ﬁle to TEGEDC Area Counsel through the Area Manager. Counsel will provide an opinion regarding the appropriateness of the tion. See IRM
, Area Counsel Pre-Issuance Review. After Counsel approves the action and the designated official signs the church tax examina- tion letter, the notice may be issued. Refer to IRM
, Issuance of Notice of Examination. Note: The designated official to approve a church tax examination under IRC
(b) is the Commissioner, TEGE. In situations where approval is under IRC
(f), such approval is to be made by the Deputy Commis- sioner for Services and Enforcement. See Delegation Order
(Rev
) in IRM
, Servicewide Delegations of Authority. (

) A summons may be issued if the church does not provide the information requested during the examination. The IRS employee should prepare a summons and forward it to TEGEDC Area Counsel for review as soon as cir- cumstances indicate that the church will not voluntarily provide the information requested. Refer to IRM
, Issuing Church Summonses and IRM
, Summons. (

, Closing Letters, Report of Examination and Mandatory Review Requirements. Attach Counsel’s memorandum to a return prepared under IRC
(b) when submitted for assessment. (

procedures.

of Summons Special Applications 25.5.8
The two-year period for completing a church examination will not be suspended during stays of summons proceedings resulting from violations of IRC 7611 procedures.

The term church includes: a. Any organization claiming to be a church, and/or b. Any convention or association of churches. A church tax inquiry is any inquiry to a church (other than an examination) serve as a determining basis for whether a church is: a. Tax exempt under IRC
(a) by reason of its status as a church, or b. Carrying on an unrelated trade or business (within the meaning of IRC
), or c. Engaged in activities which may be subject to taxation.
c. Engaged in activities which may be subject to taxation. Note: A church tax inquiry may lead to a church tax examination. (
) A church tax examination is any examination of church records or the religious activities of any church to determine if a church is: a. Tax exempt under IRC
(a) by reason of its status as a church, or b. Carrying on an unrelated trade or business (within the meaning of
), or c. Engaged in activities which may be subject to taxation. Note: A church tax examination may not take place until a church tax inquiry been completed. (

) Church records include: a. All regularly kept church corporate and ﬁnancial records; b. Corporate minute books, contributor and membership lists, and books of account, and; c. Private correspondence between a church and its members that is in possession of the church. (
) Comply with the requirements of IRC

before issuing a summons to a church to secure: a. Information requested during the examination which the church provide. b. Information about a church’s federal ﬁling requirement, and c. Delinquent returns. Note: IRC
is not applicable to routine requests as described in IRM or when the purpose of the summons is to secure information to aid in collection of liabilities already assessed. (
) A church summons must be prepared in accordance with procedures in
, Summons, Preparation and IRM
, Summons. (
) Modify the preprinted description of purpose on the summons form to the speciﬁc purpose of the church summons. Contact TEGEDC Area

a. Tax exempt under IRC
(a) by reason of its status as a church, or b. Carrying on an unrelated trade or business (within the meaning of IRC
), or c. Engaged in activities which may be subject to taxation.

a. All regularly kept church corporate and ﬁnancial records; b. Corporate minute books, contributor and membership lists, and church books of account, and; c. Private correspondence between a church and its members that is in the possession of the church.
A church summons must be prepared in accordance with procedures in IRM 25.5.2, Summons, Preparation and IRM 4.75.39.10, Summons.
Modify the preprinted description of purpose on the summons form to reﬂect the speciﬁc purpose of the church summons. Contact TEGEDC Area Counsel
for assistance in drafting the appropriate language. TEGEDC Area Counsel must review the proposed summons before issuance. (

) Refer the summons to TEGEDC Area Counsel for enforcement if a church does not comply with the summons. After reviewing the summons request and preparing the suit letter, TEGEDC Area Counsel will refer the matter to the National Office for review pursuant to CCDM
, Prepara- tion of Suit Letters. (

) If the IRS has not substantially complied with the church examination proce- dures, a summons enforcement proceeding brought by the IRS to gain to church records may be stayed by the Court until the IRS complies with
procedures. Note: The two-year period for completing a church examination will not be suspended during stays of summons proceedings resulting from violations IRC
procedures. (
) In church-related investigations, Criminal Investigation will follow the same cedures for summonses and other inquiries as in other criminal cases, since IRC
(i) states restrictions on church tax inquiries and examinations do apply to any criminal investigation. (

) The IRS may issue a summons, relating to a person’s foreign tax liability to obtain information within the United States, in response to a formal request made by a foreign Competent Authority pursuant to the provisions of an to income tax treaty, estate and gift tax treaty, tax information exchange agreement (TIEA), or tax coordination agreement with a U.S. territory. The Commissioner, Large Business and International (LB&I), and his/her acts as the U.S. Competent Authority in administering the operating of these exchange agreements. See IRM
, Foreign Initiated Speciﬁc Requests for Information and Delegation Order
(as revised) in IRM Servicewide Delegations of Authority. (

) Foreign-initiated requests for information are received by the designated U.S. Competent Authority and typically assigned to an analyst in one of the IRS Exchange of Information (EOI) offices including the Program Manager, EOI the Program Manager, Joint International Tax Shelter Information and ration (JITSIC). When necessary, the assigned analyst may solicit the assistance of IRS civil or CI personnel. If the request is determined to be under the terms of the applicable international exchange agreement, the assigned analyst will ﬁrst attempt to obtain the information requested through informal means without using a summons, except where informal means are not feasible. Refer to IRM
, Requesting Information: Overview, IRM
, Interviews: Authority and Purpose and IRM
, Foreign- Initiated Speciﬁc Requests for Information. However, do not attempt to obtain documents by informal means from ﬁnancial institutions which are found the Tenth Circuit. Refer to IRM

, Documents from Financial Institu- tions in the Tenth Circuit, for more information on this limitation. If the information requested is not voluntarily provided, and the information cannot obtained elsewhere, the analyst will prepare an administrative summons. to IRM

) Summonses may be issued to persons or entities in the United States who have control over records located abroad. These summonses are required to be reviewed by Field Counsel prior to issuance. See CCDM
), mons Provisions. Before issuing a summons for records located outside the United States, the IRS employee should consider alternative means of ing the information. (

) The IRS may issue a summons to a domestic bank to produce records of a foreign branch. Additionally, the IRS may issue a summons to a domestic branch of a foreign bank to produce records. Consult with Area Counsel, will consult with Associate Chief Counsels (Procedure & Administration) and (International) and refer to IRM
, Foreign Branches of Domestic Banks, and IRM
, Domestic Branches of Foreign Banks, for tion concerning foreign banks or foreign branches of domestic banks. (
) The IRS cannot issue a summons directly to any individual or entity located outside the United States. IRS employees seeking foreign-based information are encouraged to refer to IRM

, Procedures for Obtaining Books Records Located Outside the United States and contact LB&I’s EOI Program to determine what information could be obtained through a request for tion under an international exchange agreement. Refer to IRM

, Authority - Conﬁdentiality, and Contacts with Foreign Tax Officials. All requests for infor- mation under the provisions of an international exchange agreement must conducted through the U.S. Competent Authority. Under no circumstances should contact be made with foreign tax officials without going through the Competent Authority. (
